title: 109_s1494
content: The Act is titled the "NOAA Chesapeake Bay Watershed Monitoring, Education, Training, and Restoration Act". It establishes programs for the Chesapeake Bay office. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Authorization Act of 1992 is amended to establish the Chesapeake Bay Integrated Observing System in collaboration with various organizations in the Chesapeake Bay watershed. The Chesapeake Bay Integrated Observing System (referred to as the `System') aims to provide essential information for restoring the health of the Chesapeake Bay, including data on land use, environmental quality, coastal erosion, ecosystem health, aquatic resources, and weather patterns. The System coordinates monitoring activities, identifies data collection needs, and utilizes new technologies to gather comprehensive environmental information. The Chesapeake Bay Integrated Observing System aims to provide environmental information for the Chesapeake Bay, including collecting and analyzing scientific data, managing and interpreting information, organizing data into useful products, and supporting the development of an Internet-based information system. The development of an Internet-based information system for integrating, interpreting, and disseminating coastal information, products, and forecasts related to climate, land use, coastal pollution, environmental quality, coastal hazards, ecosystem health, aquatic living resources, habitat conditions, economic and recreational uses in the Chesapeake Bay watershed. The Director may enter agreements with other entities to provide and interpret data and information related to weather, tides, currents, sediments, nutrients, organisms, coastline erosion, and chemical processes. The Director may enter agreements with eligible entities for data collection, processing, analysis, and electronic publication of information products. Additionally, a Chesapeake Bay watershed education and training program will be established in cooperation with the Chesapeake Executive Council. The Director is authorized to award grants for a program expanding Chesapeake Bay watershed education, aimed at improving understanding of the ecosystem, providing community education for watershed protection, and meeting educational goals of the Chesapeake 2000 agreement. The Director can award grants for projects in the Chesapeake Bay watershed to nongovernmental organizations, consortiums of institutions, schools, teachers, or state departments of education. Grants under this subsection can support education and training projects on the issues of the Chesapeake Bay watershed, including classroom education and distance learning technologies. The Director considers the applicant's experience in providing environmental education projects in various settings. Grants under this subsection support education and training projects on the Chesapeake Bay watershed, including outdoor experiences, professional development for teachers, and dissemination of educational materials. Grants support environmental education projects in the Chesapeake Bay watershed, including field methods, assessment of environmental conditions, and projects to enhance understanding and protect living resources. The NOAA Chesapeake Bay Watershed Monitoring, Education, Training, and Restoration Act establishes a program to support environmental education projects in the Chesapeake Bay watershed. The Federal share of project funding shall not exceed 75 percent of the total cost. Additionally, a Stock Enhancement and Habitat Restoration Program will be established within a year of the Act's enactment. The Director, in cooperation with the Chesapeake Executive Council, will establish a Chesapeake Bay watershed stock enhancement and habitat restoration program to support the restoration of oysters and submerged aquatic vegetation in the Chesapeake Bay. Activities may include grants, contracts, and agreements for oyster hatcheries and submerged aquatic vegetation propagation programs. The Director is authorized to make grants and contracts with higher education institutions for Chesapeake Bay aquaculture education, focusing on aquaculture sciences, technologies, and improving oyster spat and aquatic vegetation production. SEC. 3. REPORT. Section 307(b)(7) of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Authorization Act of 1992 is amended to require a biennial report on Chesapeake Bay conservation efforts, grants awarded, and an action plan for research and monitoring activities. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Authorization Act of 1992 is amended to require a biennial report on Chesapeake Bay conservation efforts, grants awarded, and an action plan for research, monitoring, and data collection activities. Additionally, proposals are needed for continuing new NOAA activities in the Chesapeake Bay and integrating them with the Chesapeake Bay Program partners to meet the commitments of the Chesapeake 2000 agreement and subsequent agreements. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The subsection (h) of section 307 of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Authorization Act of 1992 is amended to define the Chesapeake Executive Council and the Chesapeake 2000 agreement. The Chesapeake Bay Commission entered into an agreement on June 28, 2000, defining eligible entities as governments, institutions of higher education, and nongovernmental organizations in the Chesapeake Bay watershed. Private entities determined appropriate by the Director may also be exempt from taxation under section 501(a) of the Code. Authorization of appropriations under section 5. Authorization of appropriations for the Chesapeake Bay Office under the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Authorization Act of 1992 is specified for fiscal years 2002 through 2010, with varying amounts allocated annually. For fiscal years 2006 through 2010, specific amounts are authorized for subsections (d) through (g) under the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Authorization Act of 1992.
